posts.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21491969
Mises argument in Human Action"l is that socialism, including communism, doesn't work as an economic system because it doesn't have a price system, which is necessary for efficiently allocating resources. Mises doesn't define socialism or communism as necessarily not having a government, but rather as systems where the means of production are owned and controlled by the state or the community instead of by individuals. In this way, the Soviet Union could be considered a communist state, even though it had a government and laws.

Some people who are into communism have argued for getting rid of the state and creating a classless society without a government like we know it. In this sense, a government might not be compatible with a fully realized communist society. But Mises' critique of socialism doesn't depend on this specific understanding of communism, and it's possible to defend Mises' argument even if you accept the idea of a stateless communist society

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21487869
censēre is a verb within the broad category of speaking, feeling, thinking, etc. that is, verbs that are often/normally accompanied by indirect speech. In English, though this is happening less and less, we often use 'that' to express indirect speech (e.g. "I believe THAT the money is still there.") In Latin this is normally done with infinitive verbs and accusative subjects (though you do sometimes see 'quod' being used like how English uses 'that', but this is more common in later Latin).
>Itaque deos hominibus colendos timendosque esse censuerunt
you could translate this as "Therefore they thought THAT (the) gods are to be/must be worshipped and feared by humans"
while the second one
>Dei hominibus timendi non sunt
"(the) gods must not be/are not to be feared by humans"

Bruh, when does this get good? I went scouring for recommendations, and pulled this one because you gave it a 5/5. So I thought, "Even if it's not as good as that, it still has to be decently entertaining." Well I'm not 25% into the book now, and it's losing me fast.

Event happen TOO fast. The PoV shifts are too rapid, and the passage of time jumps around too much. It reads less like a novel, and more like a written history of events with some flowery language here and there. Every time I get snuggled in with one character, suddenly we're leaping through time to talk about some random fuckwit who formed an army to take over some region. Then we return to the main character, and EVERYTHING has changed in their lives.

Also, they open the book with some guy doing magical shit, and then after that... nothing. No magic. Just endless power grabs and wars and platitudes. Sure, they introduce the gods pretty early. But the gods are so incredibly petty in their squabbling, that they're pretty much just regular people with super powers. Narratively, they only exist to explain why all the needless wars are happening. It's so in your face about it though. There's no mystery, no intrigue. Nothing like that. Just "HAHA! I AM THE GOD OF THIS AND THAT, SO THEREFORE I DESIRE SUCH AND SUCH OUTCOME, IT IS MY WILL.

In fact... dropped.

I read this, and it was total dogshit. Baby's first eliminative materialism tract, constantly reiterated because apparently Bakker has no faith in the reader's ability to get the point unless he beats a dead horse. It doesn't help that no relevant character really presents an alternate perspective. The book has the preachiness of a certain variety of lecturer, but with none of the depth.

All this is wrapped up in an airport thriller of below average quality. Below the average of airport thrillers I've read, not just books in general. Weak dialogue, predictable, overly reliant on character retardation, and—worst of all—just sort of boring. I would not recommend this to anyone. If Neil had been a cute girl, I could at least recommend it to yandere-appreciator cumbrains, but unfortunately Bakker did not do this.

I hope his fantasy books aren't anywhere near this vapid and their pretensions aren't as unwarranted as this book's, or I'll be forced to admit /sffg/ memed me into reading a garbage author.

>>21490334
It sounds like you're more interested in the science fiction aspects, in the original meaning of the term, than the fantasy, so I think it may be a hard sell for the average fantasy fan. In terms of the trading that requires a lot of information that may not be available, let alone current. I think if you want to have any plausibility to what you're doing you'll have to vastly limit the character's effectivesness unless there's some magic involved. A mildly similar novel I've read is The Dragon's Banker. There are a few traditionally published fantasy novels I've read that involve some finance.

Yes, the average person will find it boring, as you probably would for something you aren't interested in. It seems like it may also be noticed that you just tacked on other elements with the hope of greater appeal. That is unlikely to be satisfactory. With this kind of story you have to be satisfied with a niche audience and embrace that.

If you want to be popular, sell well, or otherwise do well you can't write that way.

posts.com:
Aquinas assumes that there are forms of knowledge above human discursive reason, because in addition to being an Aristotelian in terms of his system and basic concepts he is also a Platonist and follows Pseudo-Dionysius (a Neoplatonist) in many things relating to cosmology and supra-mundane reality. Discursive reason can and essentially must reveal concepts like "unmoved mover" to us, as these are perfectly logically consequent - any person with a normally functioning reason can understand the logical argument for the necessity of an unmoved mover, and the paradoxicality of other possibilities, like an infinite regress of causes. But reason cannot give us direct knowledge of God by itself. It can only lead us to the threshold by clarifying our conception of the world, in a sense creating the "space" in which other forms of knowledge (revelation, faith, mystical insight) will reveal God directly to our extra-discursive faculties.

Aquinas doesn't derive the personal, historically acting, eschatological God of the Bible from reason, he shows how reason is limited, and at its most purified, it basically calls out for higher forms of knowledge like intellectual intuition and revelation. He's a bit like a Kantian in that way, except instead of scepticism about knowledge of the noumenal, he justifies faith (pistis) which attunes us to the esoteric knowledge embedded in revelation, as well as forms of knowledge other than discursive knowledge for special and fortunate individuals.

>>21489541
One of the necessary characteristics of God is ultimacy, i.e. He or It has to be the final entity from which all other entities derive or on which they all depend, and (in many ways) to which they all tend or are oriented. "Higher dimensional beings" are already countenanced in Aquinas and in Pseudo-Dionysius, because Neoplatonism had them as well, they are just angels and sometimes personified hypostases. But they don't have the character of ultimacy. They can be metaphysically grounding from the perspective of beings subordinate to them and reliant on them, but if they aren't causa sui (cause of themselves), they don't stop the causal regress and explain reality. Likewise they can be extremely powerful but if they aren't all-creating it is basically meaningless. One can always just posit an even higher dimensional being as their master or creator, and so on in the same causal regress.

The point is to stop the regress. To do that you need to posit something that transcends finite being in such a way that it itself is not even a being (because it is logically of the nature of being to be determined in some way), which is paradoxical from the perspective of discursive knowledge and, possibly, even of angelic knowledge. Hence God is in a sense paradoxical and miraculous, a mystery in the full and classical sense of the term, and can only be accessed through His miraculous (and discursively equally inexplicable) choice to reveal Himself, to intervene in history in the form of Christ, etc. The only way to describe such a being is through negative theology, which was established in the Christian tradition by Pseudo-Dionysius using Neoplatonic categories, but ultimately going back to Philo Iudaeus and the Alexandrian school's approach to reconciling the mysteries of scripture with reason.

Just like in Aquinas' philosophy, ancient Greek reason basically burned itself out in its attempt at self-grounding, it had fizzled out in mutually contradictory but mutually overlapping and totally unsatisfying metaphysical schemes like the Stoics'.

>>21489608
>1. Why do we need to stop the regress? Our reality could be a simulation inside a reality with different rules.
Said reality would have the same question as to its ultimacy, its own cause. From the premise "everything has its cause" we have two options regarding an an indefinite search "up" the chain of causes: an infinite regress or a form of cause that is not itself an effect (a causa sui, cause of itself), stopping the regress. The question why we should prefer one to the other is as old as Plato. If you want to read or listen to an intelligent conversation about it, listen to the Copleston vs. Russell radio debate, as they touch on it and are baffled by each other's positions. If you want a very difficult but comprehensive treatment of the subject, read Schopenhauer's Fourfold Root of the Principle of Sufficient Reason or Nicholas of Cusa's Learned Ignorance.

>2. Why is a prime mover the God of the Bible and not just some rando?
A rando (i.e., a contingent being) that is not God would re-open the question as to the source of its own contingency, determinacy, and finitude - of its cause.

A rando that is God would still have to satisfy certain logical criteria, first and foremost ultimacy. Because Aquinas is in the Platonic and Aristotelian traditions, both of which take the highest goodness to be a self-evident quality of the highest being (the most actual, most real thing is also the best thing), partly as a means of explaining why things change and attain structure at all (because it is "better" to have structure and tend toward "perfection"), needs God to satisfy the logical criterion of being the highest good, basically Plato's True, Good, and Beautiful. If you deny the ontological reality of good (and thus of the better being higher than the worse), you are burdened with explaining why a cold indifferent highest principle would do anything at all, why chaos doesn't reign instead of order, etc. A purely material first principle is just as paradoxical as a miraculously and transcendently good first principle, if not more.

If you're asking why Aquinas thinks we should believe in the Christian God of the Christian scriptures in particular, that doesn't come from rational deductions but from faith (pistis), which itself can be rationally justified as a necessary aspect of the fully actualized human being in Aquinas' view. But ultimately only the act of faith itself can reveal the supra-rational truth of Christian scripture. Ultimately Aquinas can't do much to convince a committed Muslim or Jew that Christianity is the right one and not his. Conviction about such matters takes place at a different level, including the presence of the Holy Spirit in one through grace and faith, esoteric symbology directly revealing the mystical truth of the Trinity to contemplatives, mystical union with God, etc.

You can if you agree to the premises. Then it is a tautology: The originating cause must be an ultimate cause, i.e., beyond it there are no further causes. You can posit a "higher" cause than mundane terrestrial or sensible realities, but the question is simply raised as to the cause of that higher level of reality. If you invoke another, even higher level, the same problem occurs and a regress is evident. To stop the regress we assume that eventually it stops, i.e. there is a level of reality that is ultimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21490090
Yes, but we CAN know some limited things about those realities based on logic, is Aquinas' point, since he is a metaphysical realist regarding knowledge. Logic can at least establish the limits of what is thinkable tautologically: If we assume that reality is not an infinite regress, but must have an ultimate stopping point, then the one thing we DO know about whatever being is at the end of the chain is that it is at the end of the chain. We can make similar deductions about any contingent being: If we establish that all contingency is "creaturely," then by definition any contingent being (a giant or a simulation for example) must be creaturely.

The few things we can say about God logically are that he must be there to terminate the regress (if this premise is accepted, and most people do accept it to some degree or another), and that his being must be of a kind that is beyond the being to which we are accustomed, since the being to which we are accustomed is caused, determined being, and we are looking for an entity that could explain all of it, not just another example of it.

Of course you could say this is all just our "local" logic, and higher realities could have different logics. This is basically the Kantian position, namely, that one can't attribute the concepts in one's mind to reality itself, or see them as reflections or microcosmic versions of reality's or God's own reasoning, like the medieval scholastics and the Cartesians (including Spinoza and Leibniz) did. But this opens up a whole host of paradoxes too, and eventually dissolves into complete solipsism if pushed far enough. That's why Kant's successors tried to find a way to argue from certain principles (like that our reason, being part of reality, must in some way reflect and participate in reality) to break out of the soap bubble Kant trapped us in, and back out into some kind of metaphysical realism. Things get complicated beyond that point.

>The alternative is simply being a skeptic.
Everybody has ontological commitments whether they like it or not. An attempt to be totally neutral presumes that there is a universal, pre-determined neutral position, which would be non-neutral. This has de facto resulted in the "disenchantment of the world" and the spread of a vulgar materialism and vulgar hedonistic individualism and technology worship, which aren't neutral at all, more like leftover remnants of dead Enlightenment philosophies.

Sure, basically Aristotle defines most objects as having both essence (form) and existence. The idea is that existence is some sort of raw, unrealized potentiality (this is why you often hear classical theists referring to God as 'pure actuality'), and form is the restrictive aspect that gives that potentiality a recognizable organization. So, Aquinas defines God in these Aristotelian terms, as pure actuality/matter, without any restrictive form, which necessarily implies no restrictions placed on His attributes.

Maybe a more knowledgeable anon could unpack the moves of Aquinas sketched here:

>Another objection to Aristotle’s concept of God is that the Prime Mover is not a God of providence and of love. It took the genius of Aquinas to argue that Aristotle’s God is implicitly a God of providence and love. Aquinas reasons that God is self-subsisting existence, ipse esse subsistens. From this he deduces other properties which must belong to God. Aquinas notes that ipse esse subsistens, and actus purus and prime mover are metaphysical names of God and are applicable to one and the same substance. Thomas proves the infinitude and perfection of God from the notion of self-subsistence. God’s eternity is proved from the same notion and also by way of immutability, which is proved by God’s being simple, infinite, and actus purus, pure actuality: there can be no change or movement in God since there are no unactualized potentialities in him. That god is not body—i.e., is immaterial—is proved as part of his simplicity. His immateriality can be said to be a consequence of his being pure act, i.e., without matter.

>Now from these metaphysical properties of God (God as infinite, immaterial, pure act, etc.), these Aristotelian properties, Thomas passes on to the properties of the Christian God as he is revealed in the scriptures.
https://heptapolis.com/aristotles-concept-god

There is quite a bit more in the above essay, but it remains only a sketch of the steps Aquinas took in making out his position, rather than an explanation of the logic that undergirded each step.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't think your protagonist needs to STRICTLY be a farmboy, he just needs to come from humble beginnings and be ignorant of the wider world. This allows you to set him up for character growth, and also allows you to worldbuild extensively by showing everything to him for the first time, and having the characters more familiar with this new world explain things to him--and through him, to us, the audience, who are also encountering it for the first time.

Pic related. Harry Potter isn't GREAT but he's a great protagonist for a big story. He's not the stereotypical farmboy but he does come from humble beginnings, have hints of a great destiny, and he is a total outsider to the wizarding world, so Rowling gets to use his encounters with it to worldbuild and explain things that the rest of the cast is already familiar with. Harry is the same sort of protagonist as Luke or Perceval despite not being a "farmboy" like they are.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21490863
The problem isn't so much that it's played out, but that only a very small percentage of people in the modern world are involved in agriculture anymore. It's not a relatable origin, but a misunderstood role from a romanticised "simpler time" where people are assumed to have lived joyfully in one community until the call to action. Perhaps the most unrealistic thing about stories with these sorts of protagonists is how often they are the only child for the sake of the plot - people on farms can have big families because the kids soon become free labour.

Coming from humble beginnings is fine, and it works well because someone from humble beginnings usually wants things they don't have, and this serves to drive the plot forward because of the barriers they face and the lessons they need to learn... but whether farmboy works is probably down to the setting.

posts.name: Anonymouṡ

>>21491596
>besides Star Wars, I cannot name any other piece of fantasy fiction with a farm boy protagonist.
Perhaps not, but there are dozens, even if you take "farm boy" literally. If you broaden the concept to mean, basically, "any humble protagonist in a low-technology, probably rural setting", there are thousands. Here are the first six that came to mind:

The Belgariad (Eddings) — Garion = young-boy-on-a-farm

The Wheel of Time (Jordan) — Mat, Rand and Perrin = farmer, shepherd & blacksmith apprentice respectively

The Chronicles of Prydain (Lloyd Alexander) — Taran = "apprentice pig-keeper"

A Wizard of Earthsea (Le Guin) — Ged = goatherd (son of blacksmith)

Mort (Pratchett) — Mort = incompetent absent-minded farm boy

Sword of Truth (Terry Goodkind) — Richard = "humble woodsman"

Is it worth reading to understand the modern cultural and political milieu?
>This masterwork of interpretative history begins with a bold declaration: The Modern Age is the Jewish Age--and we are all, to varying degrees, Jews. The assertion is, of course, metaphorical. But it underscores Yuri Slezkine's provocative thesis. Not only have Jews adapted better than many other groups to living in the modern world, they have become the premiere symbol and standard of modern life everywhere.
>Slezkine argues that the Jews were, in effect, among the world's first free agents. They traditionally belonged to a social and anthropological category known as "service nomads," an outsider group specializing in the delivery of goods and services. Their role, Slezkine argues, was part of a broader division of human labor between what he calls Mercurians-entrepreneurial minorities--and Apollonians--food-producing majorities.
>Since the dawning of the Modern Age, Mercurians have taken center stage. In fact, Slezkine argues, modernity is all about Apollonians becoming Mercurians--urban, mobile, literate, articulate, intellectually intricate, physically fastidious, and occupationally flexible. Since no group has been more adept at Mercurianism than the Jews, he contends, these exemplary ancients are now model moderns.
>The book concentrates on the drama of the Russian Jews, including migrants and their offspring in America, Palestine, and the Soviet Union. But Slezkine has as much to say about the many faces of modernity--nationalism, socialism, capitalism, and liberalism--as he does about Jewry. Marxism and Freudianism, for example, sprang largely from the Jewish predicament, Slezkine notes, and both Soviet Bolshevism and American liberalism were affected in fundamental ways by the Jewish exodus from the Pale of Settlement.
>Rich in its insight, sweeping in its chronology, and fearless in its analysis, this sure-to-be-controversial work is an important contribution not only to Jewish and Russian history but to the history of Europe and America as well.

>Ziqi of Nanbo was wandering around the Hill of Shang when he saw a huge tree there, different from all the rest. Athousand teams of horses could have taken shelter under it, and its shade would have covered them all. Ziqi said, “What tree is this? It must certainly have some extraordinary usefulness!” But looking up, he saw that the smaller limbs were gnarled and twisted, unfit for beams or rafters, and looking down, he saw that the trunk was pitted and rotten and could not be used for coffins. He licked one of the leaves, and it blistered his mouth and made it sore. He sniffed the odor, and it was enough to make a man drunk for three days. “It turns out to be a completely unusable tree,” said Ziqi, “and so it has been able to grow this big. Aha!—it is this unusableness that the Holy Man makes use of!” The region of Jingshi in Song is fine for growing catalpas, cypresses, and mulberries. But those that are more than one or two arm lengths around are cut down for people who want monkey perches; those that are three or four spans around are cut down for the ridgepoles of tall roofs; and those that are seven or eight spans are cut down for the families of nobles or rich merchants who want side boards for coffins. So they never get to live out the years Heaven gave them but are cut down in midjourney by axes. This is the danger of being usable. In the Jie sacrifice, oxen with white foreheads, pigs with turned-up snouts, and men with piles cannot be offered to the river. This is something all the shamans know, and hence they consider them inauspicious creatures. But the Holy Man, for the same reason, considers them highly auspicious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Evangelion has no depth, it's a harem anime.
You were tricked into thinking it's deep because Anno flashed the Tree of Life at you a few times, mentioned some occult deep lore words, and the characters cried a lot.
If you spend any time reading up on Evangelion's production, and the occult ideas that are referenced, you'll eventually realize it's all smoke and mirrors, it's all bluff. There's nothing of substance going on in the show. This itself is a conclusion from some of the relevant occult philosophy, and maybe you'll find it worth it just to go down that rabbit hole and find out for yourself, but trust me when I say it will be no different for you whether you discover what I'm talking about or are lucky to fail to. You'll have wasted your time.
In Evangelion, nothing of substance is said, it's just a bunch of well directed/edited scenes haphazardly strung together in a largely plotless mess, and delivers a flaccid conclusion.
The execution is great, there's some good animation, but the use of music, the storyboarding, and editing is even better. That's really the best part of Evangelion: the nonverbal qualities of its production, not the story.
The story sucks.

tl;dr: you think it's deep because the giant robots fought to Beethoven. This isn't depth, it's style. If you want depth you should be looking for something other than Evangelion. If you want something like Evangelion, you should be looking at visual arts, movies, music, videogames, etc.: I can almost gaurantee you you won't be able to read anything that seems as "deep" to you as Evangelion.

To those curious the borrowings of EVA are from all German Idealism, but principly Kierkegaard, Schopenhauer, Hegel, Freud and Jung though mainly the first and last. The key is both how we interact with other people, the AT fields, and how the Absolute is anime. Basically, it's a meta anime pointing out how we've changed from a religious view of the absolute to an escapist one, where we hide away all our sufferings under an unreality such as anime. The Kierkegaard is in having to accept that reality is only really a game of escapism, accepting that so that we can move past it, then withdrawing from the posited absolute, our attachment to escapist anime, to know ourselves as we actually exist in reality.

>>21488590
No, I won't give any examples. I just don't have the energy for the inevitable arguing that will ensue. I've lost my patience for most of this conversation already.
But I will say, because I believe this is important, that there seems to be some idea that "depth = heady" or "depth = sad", but some of the great works I consider particularly deep are explicitly optimistic, positive, lighthearted, "lightheaded", easy, and generally opposed to the kind of brooding pathos you'd get from Evangelion or Apocalypse now.

And the sort of works I like and consider deep are very different from the "vapid": full of sadness, heartache, moral, political, and social complexities, issues of spirituality and religion, and great beauty.
Fine I will name the Marriage of Figaro as a deep work, full of psychosexual complexity, political commentary, and dramatic tension. It's explicitly comedic and lighthearted throughout, ending on a positive note.

There is some strain of immaturity in current year discussions of what is "deep" as if the conversations are (and they are) being held by adolescents who associate being grim with being profound.
I am simply very tired of that, hence this rant.

posts.name: Anonymous

Addendum
>>21488672
>Marriage of Figaro
This just popped into my head as an example of a work I consider "deep", due to the amount of thought it provoked, but on consideration, it was basically pop-Opera of its time. Maybe my impulse to name it leans into this inevitable e-peen measuring contest I was trying to avoid.
But I will add that something Marriage of Figaro has over Evangelion is explicit, timeless, and universal political commentary about the relation between lords and serfs, sympathetically exploring the sadnesses and joys of both masters and servants. It examines both archetypes and is fair to both: it's not a cakewalk to be a lord, and in some ways its pretty good to be a peasant..., that kind of idea.
It's also evenhanded in its exploration of the struggles of men and women and our social/sexual dynamics within power structures.
There's also a lot someone could get out of it in regards to wise ways to handle an overbearing lord (boss, teacher, parents, etc.), or examples of things that are almost universally attractive to women, which might help the losers in the audience.
Yea, it's Opera for the masses, arguably similar to Evangelion in that way, but I got a lot more out of it than I did Evangelion, especially about ways to relate to actual people, and in the evenhanded, compassionate exploration of the perspectives of multiple types of people.

>>21488851
>If you want to talk about an "externalization of the microcosmic", which I'm sort of assuming is a pretentious way of saying "a 3 dimensional character"
That's now what it means at all. The macrocosmic/microcosmic distinction comes from Faust by way of the Jungian psychological interpretation of the work. Faust I is about Faust's personal psychological development (the microcosm) and Faust II is about Faust watching how the entirety of humanity develops along an analogous trajectory (the macrocosm).
In Evangelion the entire cast, and entire story of the world with the Impacts, battles with the Angels, and Instrumentality are analogs to Shinji's internal, personal struggles which are in turn analogous to Anno's own depression and emotional complexes. Shinji is a microcosmic character whose personal problems have been elevated to the status of literally shaping the world in the narrative. That's what I meant.

Anno changed the ending in EoE in part because of fan reaction but also because the point that he wanted to make is that the fear of death, the anxiety over dissolving your individuality into the group, is what makes Shinji a living person. Shinji choking Asuka on the beach is his moment of finally enacting his own will to power and doing something he wants to do, to another person.
Its two different solutions to the same problem, but for some reason neither are acceptable to you? Does the show need to be humanistic and positive to meet your criteria?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21489855
I think I disagree, although I’m not sure for very good reasons: but I’ll play game and test my ideas here.
1. I think the way people use the word “deep” could either be to mean “this is a multilayered work with multiple layers of meaning”, so a metaphorical sort of “depth” that the observant/intelligent/educated person can penetrate, but there is also the possibility that when people use the word “deep” they are saying “this work cuts deep” or “it left a deep impression on me”, which is a slightly more feminine use of the word, suggesting the work itself penetrated the observer. In some ways this is literally true: light goes in the eye holes, music goes in the ear holes, abstract concepts go in the abstract concept hole, and consuming literally anything in any medium, even just living, has a feminine element, and one way or another something will “get to one” deeply: whether its that a piece of literature or media profoundly effects you because you received it at the right time, your friend died in a car crash, or you experience the joy of holding your first child. Idk man, in the biosemiotic sense I can understand what people mean when they say experiences are deep or deeply effecting: in the sense that the experience itself penetrates the soul of the observer.
And I do think ideas, themes, and messages can be encoded in a work, that need to be decoded through reference to external ideas or through cross referencing symbols in the work itself.

With all that said, the only level of depth I get out of Evangelion is that it’s a critique of the audience at the time: Evangelion critiques otakus, and the rebuilds critique anyone still watching Evangelion.
But even then, I don’t think the “Evangelion critiques otakus” idea is really present in the original show at all, as much as it’s something arising out of Anno making up the show as he went along, and then solidifying the idea in EoE where he directly makes fun of the audience (Shinji masturbating, showing death threats written to him, etc.).
The actual show has very little going on “within the text itself” so to speak. People bring so much into it, projecting their own philosophies and psychology reads into it all, but what’s actually there is about as complex as your average anime at the time. Indeed: even less complex and “deep” than anime classics that remain fortunately out of reach of normalfags with no real knowledge of the genre.

I could understand it much more if people said “Evangelion affected me deeply”, because despite not being layered, at all really, it does “cut deep” in terms of being very well produced: it does “make an impression” with the above average showmanship on display.

And I’ll assert again that “excavation site” “depth” can exist.

Moral degeneration and aesthetic degeneration are two completely separate things to everyone but the most boring moralists, and, in fact, often counteract each other. Case in point, Tolstoy's late authorship, which, in an attempt to become simple moralizing fables for illiterate peasants, as was the requirement for Tolstoy's philosophy of aeshtetics, became excruciatingly boring, and lost the brilliance that it had had before. The regeneration of morals led to the degeneration of the aesthetics. The exact opposite you find in something like the early Hamsun (who, hilariously in Mysteries, had Nagel say that (roughly translated) he was tired of Tolstoy's dirty, self-righteous and holy drool), where you see a complete disregard for common mores leading to that much greater aesthetic worth.

Normal distributions are one of those concepts which have enough complexity and implications to be discussed for months on end, but are only touched on briefly in modern curricula. For example, one can think of 4chan. According to the Central limit Theorem, any sufficiently complex variable can be modeled with a normal distribution. So the propensity to use 4chan, which is obviously a complex variable involving upbringing, sex, etc., can be described with such a graph. If we can assume that actually using 4chan involves a sort of high-pass filter, so that one must have a certain propensity for 4chan to even consider using it, then there's a set of shared characteristics whose aggregate describes the average 4chan user. Of course, it's not one particular trait, but some combination of anti-sociality, racism, intelligence, and misogyny which creates the average 4chan poster. To expand the site then requires one of two things. Either you force every anti-social loser to post here, or you lower this filter. Since the first option is so unlikely as to be impossible, any expansion of the userbase requires lowering the criteria for posting here. This means that, as the site grow, the average poster has experiences that are further and further from the average chudcel.
In the extreme case, one could imagine a site whose userbase includes the whole planet; that site's culture would thus be indistinguishable from modern irl culture.
To summarize, as the userbase increases the culture of a site approximates normalfaggot culture.

>>21490152
I am really drunk so it might not actually be legible
Anyways, another concept which is barely covered (if at all) in modern education but very significant is that of local versus absolute minima/maxima. The idea is that, while you're observing a local maximum, a change in either direction would cause a decrease in that variable. But that doesn't mean this local maximum is the absolute maximum. Rather, it's possible that bearing enough decrease will lead to an absolute increase. And so it's not enough to just determine a direction of improvement based on readily available conditions, we should be looking at the overall conception to determine the best outcome. Of course, the natural processes of improvement (evolution, free markets) only look at the relative value of one concept versus another, without considering their absolute potential. So it's necessary to intervene in these processes if we want to reach the best possible outcome.

Easily the most overlooked of the Lovecraft circle. Lovecraft has a whole genre named after him, and the seedy Sword and Sorcery setting is pretty much defined by Robert E. Howard. >>21487177
Late one evening he saw before him on the beach a small figure cloaked against the cold. He quickened his step but it was only an old woman walking the beach. Scarcely four feet tall. He passed her and wished her a good evening and then he stopped and asked if she was all right and she said that she was. She said that she was going to visit her daughter and he nodded and went on. He knew that he still hoped for that small and half forgotten figure to fall in beside him. Leaning into the salt wind with his hands in his pockets and his clothes flapping. He’d seen him one final time in a dream. God’s own mudlark trudging cloaked and muttering the barren selvage of some nameless desolation where the cold sidereal sea breaks and seethes and the storms howl in from out of that black and heaving alcahest. Trudging the shingles of the universe, his thin shoulders turned to the stellar winds and the suck of alien moons dark as stones. A lonely shoreloper hurrying against the night, small and friendless and brave.

He climbed into the loft and sat at the tower window wrapped in his blanket. Spits of rain on the sill. Summer lightning far out to sea. Like the flare of distant fieldpieces. The patter on the tarp he’d stretched over his bed. He turned up the wick of the lamp at his elbow and took the notebook from its box and opened it. Then he stopped. He sat for a long time. In the end, she had said, there will be nothing that cannot be simulated. And this will be the final abridgment of privilege. This is the world to come. Not some other. The only alternate is the surprise in those antic shapes burned into the concrete.

The ages of men stretching grave to grave. An accounting on a slate. Blood, darkness. The washing of dead children on a board. The stone laminations of the world with their fossil prints unreckonable in form and number. My father’s latterday petroglyphs and the people upon the road naked and howling.
The storm passed and the dark sea lay cold and heavy. In the cool metallic waters the hammered shapes of great fishes. The reflection in the swells of a molten bolide trundling across the firmament like a burning train.

He bent over his grammar in the light of the oil lamp. The straw roof hissing in the bellshaped dark above him and his shadow on the roughtroweled wall. Like those scholars of old in their cold stone rooms toiling at their scrolls. The lenses of their lamps that were made of tortoiseshell boiled and scraped and formed in a press and the fortuitous geographies they cast upon the tower walls of lands unknown alike to men or to their gods.

Finally he leaned and cupped his hand to the glass chimney and blew out the lamp and lay back in the dark. He knew that on the day of his death he would see her face and he could hope to carry that beauty into the darkness with him, the last pagan on earth, singing softly upon his pallet in an unknown tongue.

In this one >>21487474 it is immensely purple without giving any proper imagery. Like literally almost nothing concrete. What color is the loft? The water? >>21484957
>How do you determine a subject? Just wait for a spark of inspiration?

It is best to think through your fingers. Start writing and the inspiration will come. Type without stopping for 15 minutes. Potentially useful starts to sentences:

>I want to write about:
>I do not want to write about:
>my story makes me feel like:

At some point you can hit upon a phrase or an idea while you type that will grab you, and then you refocus on that. So let's say you wrote a list of shit "I want to write about: dogs that attack journalists, or butchers that build secret UFOs with sausages, or people who have too many fingers and live underground" and when you type the last one you think "Oh shit I like those fingers" so you

Make a new paragraph and start writing about people with too many fingers and just exploring that idea, shifting focus as you please, from fingers to thumbs, from the underground to the overground, to space or invisible beings, from the cosmic significance of hands, to certain realities where fingers might be more significant than we realise etc.

You essentially suspend your doubt and write through your bullshit looking for the writing that makes you forget you exist in a temporal reality.

>>21486492
Cut 'trepid', it is too much. Consider expanding the fluid image from 'leak' into a bigger image, such as the whispers pooling on the floor. Leak is a strange word for sound, so I think you have to make the image very strong to not make the reader think 'what?' and break their dreaming.

>In a dream, Henry
Sentences are better off avoiding weak words like it, and, he, when possible. Try inverting beginnings like this: "Henry, dreaming" or "Dreaming, Henry" etc.

>the bastard son
Cut 'the'. Not needed, stronger start with 'bastard' alone.

>when he emerged
>would have turned
This sounds wrong to me somehow. Tense shifting? Change to "would BE turned".

>The country has been rife with speculation
So far the writing has been very passive and it is starting to suck momentum and energy at this point. The rest of the writing suffers the same. Consider switching up the sentences, move the subjects/objects around, invert things etc. and try to add variety, because there is a definite feeling of sameness that runs through your sentence construction.

That said, I like it and you are a good writer and doing well, so ignore everything I say and do what you feel like.

>>4903816
I once wrote a science fiction short story about a war between transhumanists and bio-purists set in a future where Earth had been totally devastated by this war. The Transhumanist faction were simply better at fighting, but they had the critical weakness of requiring a ton of infrastructure in order to function. Silicon, aluminum, lithium, advanced chip manufacturing, these things all have really long supply chains that span multiple continents. So the Bio-Purists, realizing that in direct fighting they would lose, simply started blowing these things up and sabotaging the system. Some guy whose 12% remaining flesh is plugged into a flying death robot can kill a hundred Bios if he finds them--but he can't do shit if there's no electricity to recharge his battery, no replacement parts on hand, and the Swedish-produced immunosuppressants he relies on are at the bottom of the ocean because some guys in a speedboat suicide bombed the tanker transporting them across the Atlantic.

So things turn very asymmetrical, with the remaining Cogs desperately trying to cobble together enough of a functional supply system to avoid being wiped out, and the Bios systematically destroying everything that would make it possible. The story followed a joint-consciousness that is dispassionately (at first) trying to work out how this can be fixed, and slowly realizing that the Bios had argued that the entire transhumanist cause was inherently suicidal specifically because it relied on technology which in turn relied on a fragile ecosystem of production and industry and resources that was inherently unsustainable--and that once you go Cog you can't go back. This entire event wasn't so much a war as an illustration that they were right.

Near the end Pyrrhus (the Gestalt Consciousness) decides that though the Bios were idiots, they had actually intuited correctly that society was not and may not ever be ready for this, and self-destructs to spare itself the Hell-Program tortures that the renegades always used on captives.

And then I lost the fucking draft. Gonna try re-writing it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
‘In the writing state – the state of inspiration – the fictive dream springs up fully alive… This and nothing else is the desperately sought and tragically fragile writer’s process… the fictive dream or vision becoming more and more lucid, until reality, by comparison, seems cold, tedious, and dead. This is the process he must learn to set off at will and to guard against hostile mental forces. Every writer has experienced at least moments of this strange, magical state. Reading student fiction one can spot at once where the power turns on and where it turns off, where the writer wrote from “inspiration”, or deep, flowing vision, and where he had to struggle along on mere intellect. One can write whole novels without once tapping the mysterious center of things, the secret room where dreams prowl… But most stories and novels have at least moments of the real thing… it is this experience of tapping some magic source that makes the writer an addict, willing to give up almost anything for his art, and makes him, if he fails, such a miserable human being.’

--Art of Fiction: John Gardner

Every time I sit down to write, I treat it as a performance in the same way a jazz musician comps for a bit, takes a solo, plays a lead. I came to writing from music, and one of the things I love most about the medium is the fact that my improvisations are always captured in perfect fidelity, just the way I hear them in my head. If you've just started writing, you can't expect yourself to fully drape your intuition around the medium until you've been at it for a while.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21488994
I had that same urge for a long time. I remember feeling it was life and death to write my first novel when I was 25, the same age as Hemingway when he wrote The Sun. I did fuck all for another decade, and lived no life at all in the meantime. I feel like I died when I was 21 and came back to some form of life a few months ago only to find everything in ruins.
I'm not sure if I am rebuilding, relocating, or knocking down the last few walls remaining here.

There's no time but now, and if you live a life without variety, if you let every day become the same, then you lose it all because it turns to mush in your mind, and you look back on a decade or more and wonder what the fuck happened to your life, where did the time go?
Time is the measure of change, and when you have no change in your life, there is no sense of time. A year feels like a day when all you do is go to work each day and return to watch the same old films, or read the same books, in the same room, with your same self, fretting over the same things.

I had that same anxiety to do something, and ended up doing nothing except stoking the fear. Writing or not, I wish I had lived a life worth living, one where each day was not exactly the same as the last, and my life wasn't indistinguishable from season to season and year to year.

Even by Heideggerian lights I think you're misunderstanding das Man because for Heidegger, being drawn out of das Man is supposed to be rooted in the very anxiety brought about through confronting death, the possibility of impossibility. Heidegger suggests that belief in an afterlife is one of the ways people sedate each other into staying within the mode of das Man rather than getting out of it. More generally, any attempt to make you feel comfortable with death rather than feeling anxious about it is a tactic meant to keep you in das Man. He's pretty clear about this. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First you could start with Frederic Lenoir's book "The Spinoza Miracle", it's a really good introduction to both Spinoza's life and major works (The Theologico-Political Treatise, and Ethics). After that, if you still think Spinoza and his philosophy could answer your questions, you should read his "Ethics". Some people find it hard to read because the way it's structured, but i find it really easy to follow. After that you could read the Theologico-Political Treatise, but I find it optional in your particular case. You could also read his correspondence, since it sheds a bit of light on his works and should offer a bit more context, since he explains what others got wrong (also optional).
In regard to the buddhist texts, I can't really pinpoint something related to this topic. You would rather read some upanishads, such as the Mandukya upanishad, or anything related to the Advaita Vedanta (which Lenoir finds it close to Spinoza's philosophy).
I hope this is enough to get you started.

I would like to offer an opposing yet somewhat adjacent view: there is much interesting and worth learning from Buddhism. However, discussions on /lit/ on Eastern philosophy, and apposite topics like perennialism/Traditionalism/mysticism/on the nature of enlightenment, often get bogged down by Medieval-era-reminiscent “How many angels can dance on the tip of a pin?” autism.

See, for instance, truisms such as, “This very mind is the Buddha” (of Ch’an/Zen Buddhism).

>All sentient beings are replete with buddhanature. It is only due to their vexations that they do not know or perceive it. Thus, you must diligently cultivate expediencies to eradicate vexations.
—Mahaparinirvana Sutra

And also see the recursive microcosmic-macrocosmic mindfuck of Hwa Yen Buddhist cosmology, their concept of interpenetration of all dharma or phenomena, and the paradoxical absolutism of relativity (leading to a strange flickering union between absolutism and relativity, similar to optical illusions like the duck/rabbit-one, so commonly brought up as a trope for novices in perception psychology) encapsulated in the Flower Garland Sutra (Avatamsaka Sutra).

>>21485772
When I was travelling to visit family for New Year's Eve and/or belated Christmas I was separated from my luggage which held not only my clothes, but all the gifts bought for my family. In order to make it to my destination on time I had to leave without my bags.

On a train headed for a bus station I prayed, not for my material things back but a blessing on my family that I was about to see and the courage and wisdom to handle the consequences of choosing to make it to my hometown on time instead of staying behind to get my bags. The next day I went to the airport at my destination and arranged to get my bags sent to me and by the time everyone was sitting down to open gifts my luggage had come back.

There were people at Pearson International that had been in the baggage claim for days and hadn't seen their things but I was able to get mine put right into my hands. I felt blessed to say the least. I think the best way to go about prayer is not to see it like a letter to Santa Clause but more like the famous JFK quote:
>Ask not for a lighter burden, but broader shoulders with which to carry it

A wife is not a trophy to be won through prayer. Let the example of Christ help you make the hard choices you need to improve yourself and be a whole man first. As an independent equal that can be relied upon you will be in a far better position to ask someone to marry you.

Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Former Mormon here.
It's kind of amazing to see what a blow COVID was to the LDS church. Attendance figures are down by double-digit percentages across the board, around a third of eligible young men are serving missions, and a third of those are coming home early. Couple that with the ease with which anyone can access information that the church would rather bury, like the 'secret' handbooks for bishops, recordings of 'sacred' ceremonies, finance figures for Ensign Peak Holdings, et cetera, and I'd wager that the church will fall into irrelevance in a few short decades, if not sooner.
I have complicated feelings about the impending Mormon Apocalypse. Personally, I feel disgusted with the church and somewhat dirtied by my having been brought up in it. I had no concept of the metaphysics or philosophy underlying Christianity until I moved out, because I was brought up to believe that the early Church was corrupted by "Greek pagan thought" during the great apostasy, blindly accepted crypto-Gnostic and blatantly Masonic rituals and worldviews despite knowing exactly where they were cribbed from because I thought such things were examples of the beginning of the "restoration," and came up with elaborate copes for why evidence of a Jewish-descended civilization across the Americas did not exist. As a Trinitarian Christian now, I feel like I received a safari tour through every heresy ever devised.
I'm also angered by the thought that my family bought into this ridiculous system, both figuratively and literally, for generations, and so did the families of hundreds of wonderful people I met while I was a believing member. On a similar scale as Scientology, the LDS church uses its tithing funds to purchase large investment properties and generate wealth, which it dispenses to its top-level executives in the form of compensation, condominiums, paid trips, and so on, while remaining completely opaque about where its money is going and refusing to provide aid to members in need unless they meet certain conditions and exhaust all other options. Furthermore, for decades members were discouraged from holding savings that they could give as tithes instead - my own parents have as much saved from 30 years of professional white-collar work as I do from 4 years in the military.
At the same time, I know that the collapse of the system will shunt the remaining untouched Mormon youth into the maw of the secular-liberal amoral world order. I left because I wanted to know the truth about God more than I wanted to remain in the comfortable Mormon community, but most who leave do so out of anger at the lies they've been fed and so resolve to never enter another organized religion again. It's hard to blame them, and I expect that as membership rates and participation rates erode almost all who remain will do so as well. In the end only a few will be left - the general authorities, the hedge fund mangers, and a few true believers, alone among the ruins of their cult.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have just woken up and I am already immensely tired. It is my day off, and while ordinarily I awaken hoping for my off day already, here I am. As usual, I have nothing planned, I never do. Then why am I always looking forward to the weekend? Why has sleeping become more exciting than living?

What am I supposed to be living for, anyway? I have all my needs met, food, shelter, and well, I suppose that's it. I suppose that's all any animal needs to survive in a cage. Is this it? Is this my life, decade in, decade out? What I studied for, what I took out loans to accomplish?

At least animals in the wild are forced into cages. I did this. This is my life's work. I did all I was told to do. What was I thinking? I want to go back to bed so bad, to see the wild again, to run free throughout imagination. I suppose that's all I can look forward to now, that someday I will sleep, and I won't wake up. Maybe I can still make that happen. Or maybe's that's too much work.

It's now been hours I've laid here experiencing decay in real time, and I cannot sleep again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I read, and I hear the voice of a ghost. I know someone better than I've known anyone when they're on the page. Is it so much to ask to be known this way? To think that I will be called back to this earth to whisper in some ear is repugnant to me, and I ease my struggling heart with the notion that my words will never escape the gravity of my failures.

To be a shuttlecock, to feather the wind and land with rubber face.
To blemish a page with sweat, and to scratch at the yellow fleck locked in the pulp just below the inked sign of man's heart made idly public.
A mound of ash, held by the man whose faith is now suspended, broken heart stretches for an anchor but finds none, that bleak expanse yawns before him, his glasses fog with shame and tears and sweat. What was she to him now? A mound of ash. She did not care what was done with it, and so she left a hanging question, a nail not fully severed from the finger. To him, the left behind, there is no ceremony to beckon him to order. Now plain age and empty house gapes, cold gnaws his feet on placid kitchen tiles, he wears no sock, though cleanshaven, his innards swell with the stench of the unwashed.

I've awoken to a life I never anticipated having, but just gradually grew into through impassivity and lack of direction.
It pains me deeply to realize I've become the weirdo shut-in. To perceive how others view me. Gradually becoming at family gatherings an invisible presence (never stated, but I get the sense they're thinking "what exactly is that one's problem?"). Something like that. . It's a bit too late for me to develop social skills. I can't force myself beyond the surface layer of engagement with people. My social contacts today are 00.0, but in the past even when there was a semi-positive, though distant, relationship, I never could open up. I remember my roommate & my other roommates girlfriend talking about their families, and when they asked me about my own, my tongue was tied. I have plenty to say about my family members, only I couldn't bring myself to say anything.. Maybe I have nothing to say because there is nothing to me. I'm just an empty receptacle. Fill my face in and blow it Open. already Just watch it spill all over, out, and out farther into nothing. Nothing more, and nothing less. Still equals nothing.
Never been in a relationship, never had a friend group. So many nevers.. To have never been.
My roommate was a mirror image of myself. Painfully awkward and self-conscious. We were too similar to ever click well..
In high school all my memories are a series of brief awkward encounters always on the edge of any social group. Always was the kid no one really knew, no one would partner with, and so the teacher had to pair me off onto someone. So many humiliating moments. Nothing I despise more than that familiar look of pity in their eyes. I've seen it a thousand times, and it fills me with resentment every time I recall it.
Intellectually I'm a midwit. I go through phases of becoming interested in different things, but lack the discipline to learn any subject in depth. Just different passing manias: one month it's geopolitics, the next language learning, and then the next getting into whatever retarded obscure thing I saw next on here.
I'm extremely scared about securing a tangible future for myself.
I've no employable skills. Over the years I've wasted my time reading and learning many different arcane subjects, but none of which can secure me a good job, and I lack the social acumen to ever get these jobs I simply can't care about presenting myself well, which is exactly what I need to do. Wasted the past 4 years getting a degree in lit & floating through shit odd jobs.
I want to be an adult, but I also really don't want to be an adult...
I need a long term plan, but I can't decide what I want. . I'm terrified of becoming a washed up has been no kids, no family just stuck rotating through shitty mediocre grunt-level odd jobs at the age of 40. At that point I'd just kill myself since there'd be nothing more to live for.

>How is your family life?
My parents help support me. We're not exactly an emotional family, but my parents are very supportive and try their best.
My parents have their oddities . My dad is a very nervous kind of person . My mom a bit of a withdrawn misanthrope. Probably from her that I picked up the same reclusive tendencies.
Growing up my mom was a very religious Catholic, and I feel as though she never allowed me the freedom to develop my own views, but I was a skeptical kind of person, and remain so today, and would sometimes conflict due to my questioning tendencies..
>Were you social as a child?
I was always a loner. When I was young my parents hired someone to get me to speak since I was so withdrawn. After that I went through a period of being more active socially, and then began to withdraw again in high school . While I was friendly I never exactly developed close ties in middle school, . And once I started high school I disconnected from everyone I had known for some reason. I can't remember any specific reason, other than getting the sense that even when I was included it was always half-mocking, never really genuine. Being a nerdy kind of chubby kid, I began to get the sense that I was just a comical diversion to my old peers.
At the same time this girl started to bully me which for some reaosn made me want to disconnect from those I had known even more.

>John Keats was born in London on 31 October 1795, the eldest of Thomas and Frances Jennings Keats’s four children. Although he died at the age of twenty-five, Keats had perhaps the most remarkable career of any English poet. He published only fifty-four poems, in three slim volumes and a few magazines. But over his short development he took on the challenges of a wide range of poetic forms from the sonnet, to the Spenserian romance, to the Miltonic epic, defining anew their possibilities with his own distinctive fusion of earnest energy, control of conflicting perspectives and forces, poetic self-consciousness, and, occasionally, dry ironic wit.

T 1670B Nāgasena Bhikṣu Sūtra
Part 2: Dialogues

2.63. Aim of Sramanahood

The king asked Nāgasena again. “For what purpose do your people learn the Dharma and become monks?”

Nāgasena replied, “For the purpose of eradicating past suffering, present suffering, and not wanting to experience it again in the future, I learned the Dharma and become a monk.”

“Future suffering has not yet happened, so why do you prepare to learn the Dharma and become a monk?”

Then Nāgasena asked the king, “Are there, great king, rival countries and opponents who might rise up against you?”

“Yes, there are rival countries and opponents who frequently rise up to fight with me.”

“Then, is it when the enemies are coming, that you, great king, set to work to have weapons prepared, watch towers erected, and moats dug, or are they all prepared earlier?”

“All these had been prepared beforehand.”

“But why had they been prepared beforehand?”

“Because the enemies might come at any time.”

“The enemy has not come yet, why do you prepare?”

Nāgasena again asked the king, “Is it when you are hungry, that you then sow, or when you are thirsty, that you then dig a well?”

The king said, “It should be done beforehand.”

Then Nāgasena said, “For a man who is not thirsty, why should he prepare beforehand?”

“Excellent, Nāgasena.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21489963
>If the lad from this thread: >>21482098 # drops by, tell him I said I reckon the description of The Good is in the Republic because it's a warning against misologist who, I reckon, could become the worst tyrants. As for mathematical education I think pure maths and geometry are the closest thing to Plato's inexpressible principle.
Good to see you in this thread. I think your point, re: misology, has something plausible to it, but I think it falls short to this extent:

1) The philosopher is the one who experiences insight (whatever one wants to call it) into the Idea of the Good.

2) The non-philosopher does not experience insight into the Good, and, we'll suppose, is subject to becoming a misologist.

3) But every regime that isn't the philosopher-ruled kallipolis is ruled by non-philosophers, presumably subject to misology.

4) But three of the defective regimes, timocracy, oligarchy, democracy, are all better than tyranny.

5) Therefore it cannot be that the Good is necessarily introduced to ward off tyrannic misology per se.

(And it would be perhaps paradoxical; the mystical reading of Plato veers very close to misology in emphasizing and unspeakable and therefore irrational principle. I'm not saying that as a judgement, mind, just a paradoxical feature, maybe akin to, to be on topic, Plotinus' disavowal of matter while refusing to go as far as the gnostics in calling it simply evil.)

Re: mathematics, that seems to be what Socrates suggests, but it's never spelled out how (and he, after all, refuses to share his own opinion about the Good with Glaucon). One could imagine in a general way how the two might be related, but it's much harder to say how with precision. (And it's usually taken for granted that arithmetic is helpful here, but it's less clear how geometry and astronomy clearly help unless they're reduced to ratio proofs.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21490502
>Isn't the Good in the Republic to help us understand what the being the true king calls for?
A very tricky question! I suspect one has to ask what the sake of the kallipolis is for, and initially it seems to be twofold: 1) a model or paradigm through which we understand what Justice is in order to answer Glaucon's demand to Socrates to show that practicing justice provides the practitioner with some kind of good or well-being, and 2) as the simply good example of just and good political life, even if improbable to ever practically found. Once the philosopher is discovered to be the most suitable for ruling the city, attention is paid to how to rear such a specimen. But this raises the question: why do we need the philosopher to rule? To keep the city Just (and good). But why do we need the city? And it might be that the best or simply good product of the city is the philosopher it produces. Why should the philosopher be the best product of the city? Because the philosopher is the only citizen of the kallipolis who strives to know the Whole, and not just a part apart from the Whole. That is, there seems to be a kind of long argument about why political life is flawed but good, because the philosopher can only come about through the recognition of the errors of the city (= the cave). Somehow, the imperfect and flawed is the condition upon which something better can come about. (To use a, forgive me, Hegelian way of looking at it, the philosopher, as a human animal produced by nature, is that part of nature who, in inquiring into nature, brings about nature coming to know itself.)

Re: math, I imagine it has to be some argument akin to that. It's a shame the sharer of that anecdote (Aristoxones, I think?) didn't have more to share. The lack of detail makes it frustratingly speculative.

>>21489920
Language of Creation is a nicely concise intro+summary of the most essential and foundational biblical symbolism contained in one book. Flood, fire, work and rest, the axle and the wheel, the pillar/mountain, breath, the sun and moon (such as Samson and David), coverings of skin, the stranger, textiles and fringes, cherubim, the altar, the snake and the tree, chaotic hybrids, agriculture and livestock, the head and body, and so on. Rene Girard is also great for some insights on the thinking and conversion experience early Christians were likely going through subconsciously and consciously

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21489549

From the top of my head, a good place to start is 'The case for Auschwitz' by Robert-jan van Pelt. It basically covers the trail with David Irving and goes over all his arguments and debunks it with both historical and archeological evidence. It's pretty well-written too.

On a whole, though, a lot (if not nearly all) historians consider Holocaust denial for what it is -- a fun past-time by, as you indeed call it, autistic wehraboo losers living largely in an echo chamber on the internet. I've actually read some of the work by Carlo Mattogno and the style of argumentation is largely built on very ambiguous reading of source or what-if-isms which is actually a shame considering they went through the trouble of reading a lot of literature on the topic. One wonders why this energy could not be used in a more productive way but that's just life I suppose

finally, if you want a writer whose not a complete denier yet still very critical of the capitalisation/ the industry surrounding the holocaust, read Norman Finkelstein

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
AHEM AHEM
Much confusion surrounding this poem, its context, etc. I have seen it described as nationalistic. It is not. This is a medieval, Arabic poem, addressed to the poet's beloved. It's a poem of pride (an abundant theme in Islamic and pre-Islamic Arabic poetry).
Our battles are black?
This poem has confused many anons, and rightfully so. Arabic is very particular, and the translation isn't first-rate.
It would be more adequate (and even more literal) to say:
Our (martial) feats are black --grim, terrible. I assume this is a more familiar form.
Ouaqi'ou'na (the word translated into "battles") more or less means "battle-deeds". This is troublesome for the translator, he or she has already rendered "sana'i'una" as being "deeds" as well. (it more or less means our "doings", it has a moral edge to it)
It's self evident in Arabic, and loses rhyme and rhythm (and even meaning as we have seen) in translation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Oh and as an addendum...
Saf Addine is not the foremost ambassador of Arabic poetry. Mind you, he was a genius, and extremely technical at times, and had to bear witness to what turned out to be the (ultimate) collapse of Arab civilization.

But look especially into Abou Nawas and Abou Al Atahiyah. Contemporaries, rebels, friends, and rivals, who wrote very different kinds of poetry.
Abou Nawas was a Dionysian and a Persian, who breathed a world of color into Arabic verse.
Abou Al Atahiyah was an Apollonian, an Arab, and usually more philosophical, and more black (kek) in subject matter.

>>21490838
The mode of persuasion is simply different but there is still equally a literary art present.
In reading logic it is often most enjoyable to measure how fictional the content is, revel in the elegant phrasing and parse the complex ideas.
Logic is effectively the primordial literature from which other artful forms of literary expression arise when the measure of fiction, the discipline for elegance, or the complexity of the subject is made explicit.
Uniquely, nothing is easily presupposed about the work, and it is often, if not exclusively, purely egological.
Saying "These are my thoughts and represent my most exhaustive adventure into my own ability to produce thoughts" rather than holding to a form that places the author as a messenger for the struggle of some other fictional person.
It would feel unfair to me to say that something is not literary simply as a result of this admittedly jarring bold narcissism.

I haven’t read much of her poetry, but I was touched deeply by The Bell Jar. I can definitely understand why some, even many, dislike it or find it whiny. It’s definitely not perfect or some masterpiece but it is very honest. I have a lot of bipolar family members on one side, and I didn’t come out unscathed genetically. The Bell Jar really captured and articulated a lot of that experience in a way I had been grasping for but had failed to before I read it. Like when you have it all and it still comes down on you and you don’t even really understand why you itch to let go off the wheel going over a bridge because there’s nothing wrong in your life. And the only thing to live for is the fog lifting but it’s been so long since you last felt it you can’t be sure it ever really happened and you didn’t imagine it.

Not many books touched me as deeply as it did, but it was for personal reasons more than its artistry. Though it did have some great, surprising descriptions in there.

IDK, hauntology seems exactly right. You have steampunk and dieselpunk, essentially an interest in past futurism. You also see it a lot on /pol/ with people looking up to Nazi futurism, and most powerfully in the culture at large with people looking up to the 1950- early-1960s post-New Deal Consensus Era vision of what 2020 might look like.

Capitalist realism sounds exactly right but he is missing the point, which Fukuyama gets at better, although he also misses it by misreading Hegel.

There is no going back and on doing capitalism, but modern capitalism contains its own contradictions that will lead to crisis, sublation, and the emergence of a new form.

Fukuyama missed that capitalist liberalism didn't simply beat socialism and fascist-nationalism, rather is sublated core elements into itself. Every liberal state grounds its authority in nationalism. An Algerian vote for the Algerian people. If Israel was still 70% Jewish, few would accept simply giving Palestinians the vote as acceptable, legitimacy is grounded in liberalism for a certain group.

Likewise, every modern liberal state has pensions, healthcare (even the US spends trillions of healthcare for the poor and old), child labor laws, universal education, progressive income tax, etc., all socialist demands.

Modern liberalism sublated socialism and nationalism. Now mass migration undermines national identity and global problems, water rights, ocean acidification, recalcitrant mega corps, etc. also require extra national solutions to enforce socialism. The new inequality threatening social order is between the developing world and the developed one.

More sublation, the dialectical marching on. Hegel never becomes obsolete.

It has been. Engineering, and really all of the things we see in our daily lives, exist only as a special case of general relativity where velocities are near zero, at least compared to c. When this is the case, the effects of special relativity are so small as to be unnoticable, and the results of general relativity are roughly equal to those of newtonian mechanics. But newtonian mechanics only exists as an assumption, similar to how engineers will approximate trig identities for small angles with [sin(x) = x], while everyone knows this isn't really true.

posts.com: I’m about 150 pages in. Loving it so far. Zola picked a setting/subject matter which allows any mode of the variable storytelling he employs to grab immediate interest and retain it. Multi-paragraph descriptions of the hellish “fields” surrounding the coal mine are ever-changing and unnerving enough to be interesting in themselves. Illumination of the depths of the coal mine as well as the minutiae of the workers’ tasks and struggles is equally interesting. But, most of all, the interpersonal stories and generally wide perspective which the omniscient narrator is able to communicate (he depicts the mining town/structure IN FULL) is something I really did not expect. Highly recommend. And, yes, it is very political. The workers are abused and angry.

posts.com: What's the difference between fantasy, surrealism and magical realism?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Fantasy is a genre that involves elements of magic, mythical creatures, and otherworldly settings. It often takes place in a fictional world and follows a set of rules and laws that are different from our own.
>Surrealism is a genre that involves elements of the irrational, the absurd, and the illogical. It often portrays the world in a way that is dreamlike and disorienting, using techniques such as distortion, juxtaposition, and irrationality to create a sense of the surreal.
>Magical realism is a genre that involves elements of the fantastical or unrealistic, but in a way that is integrated into a realistic setting. It often involves the use of magic or mythical elements in a way that is accepted as a normal part of the story's world.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21490841
The other anon missed a key difference. In Magical Realism, the fantastical elements are typically uncommented on by many of the characters and are written as having a kind of immanence and embededness in a world, perhaps as symbols of fate or chance or God. In Fantasy, the unreal elements have a more defined a juxtaposed role in relation to the non-magical elements. There’s the strong dichotomy between the elements of the Harry Potty World devoted to wizards and muggles. Whereas, in 100 Years of Solitude, Arcadio’s blood carving an unrealistic pathway through Macondo takes on a more symbolic, disjunctive, “mundane” place in the film.

I'm not saying God is real or not but I'm having trouble understanding why you keep trying to fit God within a materialistic framework, as if the conception of an omnipotent God, let alone a God of spirit, needs to follow the rules. Sure the universe all-encompasses the material plane, but God is not material. Sure material objects can't travel outside of or backwards in time, but he's not even subject to time in the first place.

I appreciate your "show me the money" approach. Personally my deal has become a frustration with atheist types who speak of morality or values like they exist in and of themselves, rather than being relativistic taboos and social norms that are ultimately arbitrary, at least in a material world. And half the time it seems their quest for truth stops being a quest for knowledge, and becomes more of a means to feel superior in knowledge to others. I don't know man, most people I talk to seem to have their minds composed of half-baked axioms and truisms. Lately I've just been trying to step back and make some semblance of it all.

Trannies are pitiful but I see them more as a product of decadence than of some bogus spiritual belief. I don't see many trannies say they have the wrong spirit trapped in their body but rather society is trying to impose arbitrary gender norms onto their tabula rasa.

posts.com:
We need yet another progression of the Hegelian dialectic of the avant-garde/experimentation in the arts and literature (e.g. if the thesis is a conformist, traditional, archaic conception of art, that it should adhere strictly to classical norms and all deviation is failure to be art, and the most radical antithesis of this in the history of avant-garde literature and the arts is something like Dadaism, a possible synthesis would combine both experimentation which pushes the boundaries of what art can do, with a classical rigor, attention to detail, great talent, and a clarity which doesn’t fall into obscurantism-for-obscurantism’s-sake).

Trendy as it is to hate on Burroughs and various others of the European and American postmodernist and modernist writers, they still made some pretty damn good works, and the frontiers they opened up for us have not even been fully explored yet. Far from it. Burroughsian cut-up, Nabokovian or Borgesian metafiction, intensely psychological Faulknerian or Woolfian stream-of-consciousness, Dos Passos’ analogous non-linearity in his U.S.A. Trilogy … where are the successors to these intensely committed eccentrics and iconoclasts?

Despite the degeneracy of “Naked Lunch” and the gratuitous homosexual erotica, it has some genius writing in it.
