posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Like many novelists whose modernity we indulge, William Burroughs is essentially a writer of 'good bits'. These good bits don't work out or add up to anything; they have nothing to do with the no-good bits: and they needn't be in the particular books they happen to be in. Most of Burroughs is trash, and lazily obsessive trash too -- you could chuck it all out and not diminish what status he has as a writer. But the good bits are good. Reading him is like staring for a week at a featureless sky; every few hours a bird will come into view or, if you're lucky, an aeroplane might climb past, but things remain meaningless and monotone. Then, without warning (and not for long, and for no coherent reason, and almost always in The Naked Lunch), something happens: abruptly the clouds grow warlike, and the air is full of portents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21490376
How can anyone find his writing voice dull is beyond me, but much of his work is plotless and his characters are usually ciphers. The normie reads him for the prose, the intellectual reads him for the vision (and yes, the landscape descriptions are part of it). The midwit rages against him.

I reckon you should come back to the book after a while again. I have enjoyed David Holloway's essay on McCarthy's late modernism which delves into his use of language. That and Diane Luce's "Landscape as narrative commentary". Usually readers dislike the landscape descriptions because they can't sense a greater utility for them within the text (the worst kind being the pseud who professes literary knowledge but wholly lacks cognitive intelligence), these essays might help with that.

posts.com: There is no such thing as an accurate IQ test online, PERIOD. The ONLY way to get an accurate IQ test is to go to a psychologist who is licensed to administer the test. Why is this the only way? Because an accurate test is more than just questions and answers. You need the psychologist there with you while you’re taking your test. The psychologist needs to be able to gauge your overall mood (which really does affect the score), time how long it takes you to answer some questions or perform various tasks, and evaluate your responses to open-ended questions. A computer can’t currently do any of these things. You need to go to a psychologist.

>>21487429
The Roman Empire was built through treaties and cooperation with local elites, not the brazen self-interest of the Melian Dialogue.
The Persian Empire was beaten by Greeks farmers and potmakers. Also a complex system of alliances and satrapies, that was threatened by rebellion whenever the centre lost control, see the Egyptian Revolt in Thucydides.
Once we get to a point where technology is a effective force multiplier the weak can no longer oppose the strong on their own, and the powers who can effectively oppose the actions of another come from further afield. I don't think that this undermines Thucydides' argument in the Dialogue though.
Could the Ionians have organised themselves and effectively fought off the Athenians on their own? Unlikely, given the difficulty of organising and fighting the simultaneous revolt that would have threatened Athens hegemony. In Thucydides he makes it clear that the isolated rebellions against Athens' League/Empire were no threat to its power.
But Athens' imperialism was still opposed by rival powers, particularly Sparta and Persia. The Africans weren't going to be able to make a serious defense of themselves against European Colonialism (which, just like the Roman's still required the cooperation and compliance of existing local elites), but the Great Powers of Europe were constantly treating and compromising between each other. None of them, even the British Empire, was able to enforce its will with impunity. So instead of these nations running roughshod over the continent and the strongest grabbing what they can, you have the Berlin Conference.
Russia and China couldn't spread Communism and can't even take back what they claim is their own territory.
America between 1991 and 2014 is probably the closest the world has ever come to an undisputed hegemon, able to enforce its will in the Balkans, the Gulf, Iraq, Afghanistan (for a while at least). I don't think it has the same power today for several reasons; war weariness and dysfunctional government, the Western World's loss of unity, rising anti-American sentiment, the slow rise of powers like China.
Ultimately technology Thucydides wouldn't have dreamed off have made possible for one power to fight the rest of the world more effectively, but I don't believe we're at the point, or ever will be, where one nation holds such an insurmountable superiority over their subjects and rivals that they can act as the Athenians did in the Melian Dialogue. The purpose of the Dialogue is to show that the Athenian's hubris had reached the point that they believed they were invincible and that they could simply take what they wanted and do as they wished- a sentiment that Thucydides had forshadowed as early as the speech of the Spartan Tribune at the very beginning of the War. This belief was fatal to Athens and only polarised its "allies" against their rule.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because the Greek pagan religion consists of a dispersed series of ethical lessons learned from anthropomorphized nature forces ruled by a higher concept of idealized man (Zeus as King and Head of Household). As Greek culture develops, they use stories of more and more anthropomorphic near-Gods, like Achilles, to add to that ethical fabric, until eventually the human and the nature Gods are syncretized and through apotheosis become a singular, higher God-as-Man (Mithras, later Christ).
The Iliad and Odyssey are about men encountering adversity that leads to the development of better ethics. Iliad is Macrocosmic, Odyssey is Microcosmic (I think).

>The purpose of the Dialogue is to show that the Athenian's hubris had reached the point that they believed they were invincible and that they could simply take what they wanted and do as they wished- a sentiment that Thucydides had forshadowed as early as the speech of the Spartan Tribune at the very beginning of the War. This belief was fatal to Athens and only polarised its "allies" against their rule.
While I take it that Thucydides is contemptuous of Athens' attitude, I also take it that he indicates that the Sicilian disaster could've gone otherwise, and that it's failure is more a matter of religiosity (fear of ill omens after the desecration of the Herms, Nicias' response to an eclipse during the expedition). Athens doesn't fall because of hubris; he seems to indicate that the hubris of an Alcibiades could've well accomplished the Sicilian expedition.

As for the Sicilian Expedition, I think that he's pretty damning of Athens' democracy, which allowed the passion and self-interest of the mob free reign, as the ultimate cause of Athens' defeat. Athens had brilliant generals and unmatched wealth and power, but it was undermined by its own decision making process, the people least qualified to make military decisions were empowered to make them. The end result is Demosthenes and Nicias dragging their feet until they're routed at Syracuse.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21490525
I agree with almost everything you say, but I'm still persuaded he thinks, to his chagrin, that Alcibiades could've pulled off the expedition; what's interesting about Nicias' failures, is that he's the most "Spartan" of the Athenians, i.e., the least like them in their democratic character, and yet he bears the greatest responsibility for their failure in that episode.

It is interesting to think about what his purpose was though in juxtaposing the Melian dialogue with the terrible mess of Sicily, just as he juxtaposes Pericles' funeral speech, with its admission that the Athenian empire is a tyranny, with the plague. The initial experience of reading the latter is to connect Athenian hubris with the suffering of the plague, but then Thucydides indicates their disconnect in noting that it was as bad as it was because the country people were crammed into the city so they wouldn't be preyed upon by the marauding Spartans, and the plgue happened to unfortunately coincide.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Three options really.
1. Read books written either for a general audience, or in a less descriptive style, and thus have less challenging vocabulary.
2. Slow down your reading pace and look up the words and concepts you don't know. You can either do it as you encounter words or make note of them and look them up later.
3. Use context clues to guess the meanings, and skip past the things you don't immediately understand.

2 seems like the best option to me, since it will make this less of a problem for you as you familiarize yourself with new words and become a stronger reader. It may retard your reading pace to a degree you aren't willing to tolerate, in which case option 1 is probably your best bet. I don't think you should just guess and plow ahead, since like you say, you miss out on a lot that way.
